componenttext: Yes, okay. So Julien, remember, when we set a goal that we were going to cut the lag that we experienced between actual and authorized by 50 basis points by 2018. And that goal is still something we're very focused on, some things have changed, of course, authorized ROEs have fallen a bit as you well know. So I think in for us to continue to improve ROEs, we really have to cut that lag by more than half and get closer to actually earning the authorized ROEs, which is, I think, more realistic for us than before because of some of the settlement agreements we've entered into. So count on us to show steady ROE improvement as we proceed down the 5-year path.

componenttext: First, let me clarify, as you mentioned, Ben, authorized ROEs, specifically uptick in Minnesota obviously have come down, [indiscernible]. So when we run the math now and we look at your blended rated authorized ROE with the 9.2% number from Minnesota baked in there, it wasn't what you earned over a 12-month period, what is the lag right now that you have in the overall utility system?

componenttext: The overall utility system or NSP-Minn?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, this year, Ali, we're probably around 9%, right? And so I think if you blended all of our authorized ROEs, it probably be about 9 6, roughly around there. So you got -- so that would be 60 basis points of lag, all right? It's less than what
componenttext: Well, I mean, this year, Ali, we're probably around 9%, right? And so I think if you blended all of our authorized ROEs, it probably be about 9 6, roughly around there. So you got -- so that would be 60 basis points of lag, all right? It's less than what we had before. Remember, when we first initiated that closed the gap, it was more like 100 basis points of lag. So I think the challenge and the opportunity for us, Ali, is to -- for example, in Minnesota, clearly, that was a compromise 9 2, it's not the ROE we would have preferred to have. However, when you look at the comprehensive settlement, we have a much better shot than we've ever had before of actually earning our allowed returns. And recall that in Minnesota, we have been lagging even frankly more than 100 basis points. So we'll get at it differently. We got a lower blended ROE base, but I think with multiyear plans, comprehensive multiyear plans, we can probably do better than just cut the lag in half. And that's the plan.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think, we do -- I won't say that we do have a regulatory amortization asset in 2017 that will create a bit of a headwind in Minnesota, all things equal. Our cost initiatives continue to gain traction, and we continue to stay focused on 2 critical aspects of shareholder value: growing rate base with our steel for fuel strategy; and keeping our costs as low as they possible can be, as we've done over the last 3 years, while not sacrificing reliability and not deferring necessary maintenance.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

So if I'm hearing it right, that's all now part of the base program, and then you've extended it by a year. First of all, just want to be clear, is that correct?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ali, I think that's right on the capital program. This is Bob. On the capital program, we had the base case and the upside capital that we used to disclose and for clarity purposes, we put it all in one sort of capital forecast. As we've talked histo
componenttext: Yes, Ali, I think that's right on the capital program. This is Bob. On the capital program, we had the base case and the upside capital that we used to disclose and for clarity purposes, we put it all in one sort of capital forecast. As we've talked historically about I think we realized most of that upside case capital, and then we put additional wind and renewable development opportunities in our forecast.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ali, I mean, I don't have it in front of me, but that 2.5, you're right, it had Rush Creek, it had like I think [indiscernible] 300 million of gas reserves. Of course, we're not going to do that now. It had some advanced grid opportunities I believe th
componenttext: So Ali, I mean, I don't have it in front of me, but that 2.5, you're right, it had Rush Creek, it had like I think [indiscernible] 300 million of gas reserves. Of course, we're not going to do that now. It had some advanced grid opportunities I believe that is associated with the North in Minnesota. And then, we had some, I think, other renewable opportunities. So to Bob's point, we basically have achieved the upside CapEx just with renewables. And again, the clarity we've seen with steel for fuel is really unique for us, and I think we'll continue to look for opportunities to transition the fleet, achieve remarkable carbon emission reductions at no additional price point to the consumer.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: They're -- we anticipate advanced grid in both Colorado and Minnesota. There might be some upside to this capital forecast, but I would -- but basically, that's been captured in the 18 4 that you're looking at.

componenttext: I see. Am I thinking about that correctly? Or how you're thinking about that now?

componenttext: Ali, I think you're spot on. I think you take that growth rate. We don't need to issue equity. We have an incredibly strong balance sheet. And so if we can see the ROE improvements, that will just drive you beyond the 5.4%.

componenttext: These guys nailed most of the questions I wanted to ask, but just to be clear, looking at your CapEx forecast now versus your prior CapEx forecast, the biggest delta is renewables, and that includes the plant that you've already had approved. The remaining CapEx is the assumption that you get the 750-megawatt self-build approved? Or is it that you get the 750-megawatt self-build approved, and then there's other placeholder CapEx for further renewables in the plan?

componenttext: To get you to the 18 4, you're right about Rush Creek in Colorado, which is approved. It also assumes that we have the opportunity to build half of the RFP. We think our self-build proposals are very compelling. And we could also get there through potentially build on transfer. But the assumption is, that the capital associated with that RFP, half of that accrues to our shareholders and rate base. That leads a delta of about $1.5 billion, which are opportunities that we think are spread across all of our jurisdictions. We certainly could do more than 50% in Minnesota. I think there's more opportunities to do more in Colorado. And frankly, Greg, when you look at the economic price point that we believe that we are seeing with wind, I think we have opportunities potentially in Texas and New Mexico to just on the economic merits alone.

componenttext: I wanted to focus on rate base growth like some of the other questions. But -- in particular the kind of I think accelerated nature of that rate base growth within a potential 2016 to 2021 plan. So if you look at your Minnesota RFP, you have anticipated start of construction for some of those projects in the middle of 2017, and then coming online, kind of loosely before 2020. Is there potential to, if you're successful there, do that faster? And then when you combine that with the Colorado wind project coming online, I think the fourth quarter of 2018, really frontload or find that some of the rate base growth is frontloaded towards the 2018 to 2019 period?

componenttext: May be something in 2019, but I think that's the practical realities of construction seasons, et cetera, probably -- I mean, I think we've got our best estimate.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And secondly, on the dividends, when you look at your capital plan here, that's increased a lot since the prior one. And you combine that with a fact that you don't need, I think, any equity internal or external. How do you think about your 5% to 7%
componenttext: Okay. And secondly, on the dividends, when you look at your capital plan here, that's increased a lot since the prior one. And you combine that with a fact that you don't need, I think, any equity internal or external. How do you think about your 5% to 7% dividend growth guidance that you had previously laid out?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's pretty safe and pretty sustainable. I think, as you know, this was a delivered strategy that we had. We embarked upon an aggressive at the time, aggressive CapEx spend a decade ago and we deliberately do in that time frame grow our to s
componenttext: Well, I think it's pretty safe and pretty sustainable. I think, as you know, this was a delivered strategy that we had. We embarked upon an aggressive at the time, aggressive CapEx spend a decade ago and we deliberately do in that time frame grow our to slower than our earnings growth, and that created a fortress balance sheet for us. So now, we have a modest payout ratio of 60%, 61% payout ratio. I think that's pretty low compared to our peers. It gives us a lot of what I would call dry powder. [indiscernible] on the 5% to 7%. Although what we have, if interest rates start [indiscernible] and you see kind of the industry headwinds that will come with that, we certainly could step back and work with our board and determine if there's something else we need to do. I'm not saying we're going to do that, but it's just when you have a strong balance sheet deliberately created, it creates far more opportunities to reward shareholders. And that's something we're pretty proud of, quite frankly.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then, just one more real quick, if I could. headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: I was wondering, in terms of regulation around these renewable project or rate regulation around these, what's the current method that you expect to go forward with? I.e., is it just your traditional backward looking type of rate filings? Or is there a potential there to convince your regulators that with these multibillion type of investments, you could get rate riders or some kind of return [indiscernible], something like that?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think what we're talking about here in Minnesota would be eligible for rider recovery. We've had those mechanisms in place for a while. So I think, recovery will be concurrent. The $1.5 billion that I talked about out, that'll just depend
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think what we're talking about here in Minnesota would be eligible for rider recovery. We've had those mechanisms in place for a while. So I think, recovery will be concurrent. The $1.5 billion that I talked about out, that'll just depend on what jurisdictions we do that in. Some of will be eligible for riders. Some we might propose some sort of enhanced type recovery mechanisms as you suggest, Travis. So I think we're in really good shape with the renewable spend and getting recovery that doesn't have lag associated with it.

componenttext: Similarly, Travis, in Colorado, the recovery of the Rush Creek windfarm is through riders as well.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one more general question. Obviously, the steel for fuel, nice strategy for you guys. Was there any push back on the regulatory front? I mean, is there anybody saying no way, we should be doing this or we shouldn't be allowing Xcel to be doing t
componenttext: Okay. And one more general question. Obviously, the steel for fuel, nice strategy for you guys. Was there any push back on the regulatory front? I mean, is there anybody saying no way, we should be doing this or we shouldn't be allowing Xcel to be doing this?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know. I think people are pretty excited about it, actually. I mean, when you can -- let's talk about the Upper Midwest. When you can show regulators a plan to achieve 60% carbon reduction and do that at no incremental price point from a -- to more
componenttext: I don't know. I think people are pretty excited about it, actually. I mean, when you can -- let's talk about the Upper Midwest. When you can show regulators a plan to achieve 60% carbon reduction and do that at no incremental price point from a -- to more traditional plan, it's pretty exciting. And no, we haven't seen pushback at all, we've seen a lot of excitement. In fact, I expect people say, can you do more, which usually [indiscernible] work. And so no, I think it's created really good alignment with our stakeholders, quite frankly.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just going back to the revenue [indiscernible] rate base versus the lack of growth in power demand. I mean, I understand that renewables look cheaper than conventional power plants. But what happens with the assets that you have in the rate base? And w
componenttext: So just going back to the revenue [indiscernible] rate base versus the lack of growth in power demand. I mean, I understand that renewables look cheaper than conventional power plants. But what happens with the assets that you have in the rate base? And when there's no growth in power demand, then you keep adding generation assets?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Angie, I think that's a really good question, but let me try to answer it this way. I think what we're really doing with wind particularly is just really buying the fuel we're going to use tomorrow on sale today. So when you think about it -- I mean
componenttext: Well, Angie, I think that's a really good question, but let me try to answer it this way. I think what we're really doing with wind particularly is just really buying the fuel we're going to use tomorrow on sale today. So when you think about it -- I mean, it's not that it doesn't open up the dialogue for early retirement coal plants, but essentially, what you're doing is you're just placing fossil fuels with wind. So you might still have the generation plant, the fossil generation plant, but you don't have to use it as much natural gas, even coal, when you're displacing that fuel with wind fuel. Does that make sense to you?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It completely does, but just my question would be more -- I mean, you could buy this wind power from an outside provider that could probably use higher leverage of that project and granted the cost of capital, would be probably slightly higher than yours,
componenttext: It completely does, but just my question would be more -- I mean, you could buy this wind power from an outside provider that could probably use higher leverage of that project and granted the cost of capital, would be probably slightly higher than yours, but again, the leverage ratios would be higher, so net-net, I mean, the cost of power would probably be similar and I know that, that would be an earnings [indiscernible], but I'm just trying to figure out, from a regulatory risk perspective, if adding renewables through the rate base in the absence of [indiscernible] growth is actually a low risk growth strategy?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think -- I mean, whether it's contracted for or added to rate base, I don't think that influences very much your concern. I think maybe broader based, I don't think our rate base self-build proposals are going to -- are they going to cost compet
componenttext: I mean, I think -- I mean, whether it's contracted for or added to rate base, I don't think that influences very much your concern. I think maybe broader based, I don't think our rate base self-build proposals are going to -- are they going to cost competitive, even with the leverage [indiscernible] banking on our strong balance sheet to support that was an element to that. And I think our regulators were well aware and appreciate the benefits of utility ownership. So I really think that when you pencil out the numbers, you see how compelling, particularly when you do on a fully holistic basis, how compelling our proposals are.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's also important [indiscernible] that there is some of these wind resource are being added to reflect the fact that there are coal plants being retired in the future. So we're just taking opportunity to capture the full PTC, so maybe the wind [indiscer
componenttext: It's also important [indiscernible] that there is some of these wind resource are being added to reflect the fact that there are coal plants being retired in the future. So we're just taking opportunity to capture the full PTC, so maybe the wind [indiscernible] before. Some of the coal requirements [indiscernible] Sherco, I think we're trying to accomplish that.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Angie, Paul made a great point. Because when we're talking about early retirement coal plant, this is our resource plan. And we're the ones that are leading the decarbonization of our fleet. And I think we will show that we can build wind competi
componenttext: Yes, and Angie, Paul made a great point. Because when we're talking about early retirement coal plant, this is our resource plan. And we're the ones that are leading the decarbonization of our fleet. And I think we will show that we can build wind competitively, and I think we've earned the right to own wind in our backyard. And it's all part of an overall plan. And again, I think it does require alignment with your regulators, but I think we have it.

componenttext: It's Andy Levi. Actually, just 2 small questions. One is just more around the amount of debt that you plan to issue over the next several years. And I guess, again, the whole scheme of things, it's not that important. But just why is it $5 billion? componenttext: Because it's still, Shelby, it's very modest. And as you know, we've always had the philosophy, there's a benefit of strength in numbers. You get a -- if you're an operating utility and as part of a larger group, you do get a consolidation benefit, provided there is an excessive leverage at the Holdco and we're not even close to that. All of our utilities benefit from being part of a bigger group, and that's always been our approach and that will continue to be our approach. And we'd never do anything that would be harmful to the credit ratings of our utilities. And I think our track record speaks for itself on that.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy's 2016 Third Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Bob Frenzel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy's 2016 Third Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Bob Frenzel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition, we have other members of the management team in the room to answer your questions. 
This morning, we will review our third quarter results, initiate 2017 guidance, update you on recent business and regulatory development and update our 5-year capital forecast, financing plan and rate base growth. 
As a reminder, some of the comments during today's conference call may contain forward-looking information. Significant factors that could cause results to differ from those anticipated are described in our earnings release and our filings with the SEC. 
I'll now turn the call over to Ben.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul, and good morning, everyone. Today, we reported third quarter GAAP and ongoing earnings of $0.90 per share compared with $0.84 per share last year. Year-to-date, we're $0.07 per share ahead of last year, and as a result, we're narrowing ov
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul, and good morning, everyone. Today, we reported third quarter GAAP and ongoing earnings of $0.90 per share compared with $0.84 per share last year. Year-to-date, we're $0.07 per share ahead of last year, and as a result, we're narrowing over 2016 guidance range to $2.17 to $2.22 per share from the previous range of $2.12 to $2.27 per share. We still anticipate earnings in the middle of the range. We're also initiating 2017 earnings guidance of $2.25 to $2.35 per share, which is consistent with our long-term EPS growth objective of 4% to 6%. 
We had a productive quarter, and we continue to make progress on investment plans and regulatory issues. I'll briefly touch on some of the highlights. 
Today, we are updating our 5-year capital forecast and you will notice a significant increase in renewable investments. Therefore, I'm going to spend a few minutes discussing our steel-for-fuel strategy. Our service territory is unique in its concentration of renewable rich resources. For example, the capacity factors for wind generation are approximately 50% in Minnesota and Texas and about 45% in Colorado. When you combine high capacity factors, a strong transmission network and the extension of the production tax credit, it all translates into low renewable energy cost for our customers. Today, we can add wind energy, which meets or beats the cost of fossil generation resources. Because of the strong wind resources in our backyard, we have the unique opportunity to invest in renewable generation in which the capital costs are offset by fuel savings. Therefore, we are lowering the [indiscernible] profile of our generation fleet with significant fuel savings, which allows us to grow our renewable portfolio with no impact to customer goals. A prime example of our steel-for-fuel strategy is the Rush Creek wind project in Colorado. In September, the Colorado Commission approved our request to develop the 600-megawatt wind farm with a capital investment of approximately $1 billion. We will start initial work on the project this year, and it's expected to go into service in 2018. Another example is in Minnesota, where the commission recently approved our resource plan, which includes the early retirements of 2 coal units at our Sherco facility and the addition of a significant amount of renewable energy. In accordance with the resource plan, we have issued an RFP to add up to 1,500 megawatts of wind generation. This week, we filed a self-build proposal to develop 750 megawatts of wind generation, which will meet half of that resource need. We believe that our projects reflect competitive pricing and are confident that the commission will approve our proposal in the first half of 2017. We expect both of these wind projects will generate hundreds of millions of dollars in fuel savings for our customers, which will more than offset the capital cost, highlighting the benefit of our steel-for-fuel strategy. 
Turning to the operations side of the business. More than a decade ago, we partnered with a group of smaller utilities to form CapX2020 and transform the transmission grid in the upper Midwest. That transformation was made a reality with the recent completion and energizing of the 156-mile Hampton-Rochester-La Crosse transmission line. CapX2020 has now invested $1.9 billion in completing 4 high-voltage transmission lines, totaling nearly 725 miles. A fifth project in South Dakota is scheduled for completion in 2017. These transmission projects are addressing the liability needs and increasing access to renewable energy across the Upper Midwest. 
I'll now turn the call over to Bob to provide more detail on our financial results and outlook in addition to our regulatory update.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben, and good morning. Today, we reported GAAP and ongoing earnings of $0.90 per share for the quarter versus the $0.84 per share earned last year. The most significant earnings drivers in the quarter include: higher electric and natural gas mar
componenttext:
Thanks, Ben, and good morning. 
Today, we reported GAAP and ongoing earnings of $0.90 per share for the quarter versus the $0.84 per share earned last year. The most significant earnings drivers in the quarter include: higher electric and natural gas margins, which increased earnings by $0.15 per share, largely due to rate increases and capital rider recovery for infrastructure investments, along with sales growth and favorable weather. We also realized the lower effective income tax rate due to higher PTCs from wind projects, which increased earnings by $0.02 per share. Partially offsetting these positive drivers were increased depreciation expense largely due to capital additions and reductions in excess depreciation and reserves, which reduced earnings by $0.06 per share and higher interest and O&M expenses, which, combined, reduced earnings by $0.05 per share. 
Our third quarter electric sales came in stronger than expected and increased 1.6% on a weather-adjusted basis. We saw positive sales growth in the residential and C&I classes. We continue to experience strong customer growth of approximately 1% for both our electric and our natural gas businesses. While we're happy to see a quarter of strong sales, it's a little early to call it a trend, and our year-to-date weather-adjusted electric sales remain relatively flat. Therefore, we remain cautious on the sales outlook and anticipate flat year-over-year sales. 
We're very focused on managing our cost structure for the benefit of our customers. Our year-to-date O&M expenses are approximately 1% above last year. We experienced higher storm cost and maintenance expense in the third quarter and expect full year O&M to be slightly above 2015 actuals. We continue to mitigate O&M increases through our efforts to improve productivity through capital investment and ease of technology, and we expect to carry this effort into the future. 
During the quarter, we made significant progress in a number of proceedings across our territories. You'll find more details in our earnings release, but let me provide some highlights. 
Consistent with our strategy to implement longer term rate plan in our jurisdictions, we reached a preliminary settlement with the majority of parties in our Minnesota electric rate case, which will provide revenue certainty through 2019. The terms for the full year plan include: an ROE of 9.2% and an equity ratio of 52.5%, an annual sales true-up that continued use of all existing riders, a 4-year rate case stay-out provision, a property tax true-up and a capital true-up mechanism. We expect an ALJ report in March of 2017 and a final commission decision in June of 2017. As a reminder, interim rates subject to refund are in place while the commission considers the case. 
We're pleased to announce that we've reached a settlement and agreement in principle in our Texas rate case, and hearings have been vacated. We're working on documenting the settlement and plan to file it in the fourth quarter. Although we can't provide any details until the documentation is finalized, we believe that the settlement is positive and reflects a growing constructive regulatory environment in Texas and New Mexico. 
Finally, we also have a pending rate case in Wisconsin where we requested a revised rate increase of approximately $35 million between electric and natural gas. Just yesterday, the Wisconsin commission verbally approved a combined increase of approximately $27 million, which reflects complete recovery of our requested natural gas rate increase and an adjusted electric rate increase. Final rates will be implemented in January. 
Turning to earnings guidance. Based on our year-to-date results, we are narrowing our 2016 ongoing earnings guidance range to $2.17 to $2.22 per share. Previously, the range was $2.12 to $2.22 per share. We are also initiating our 2017 ongoing earnings guidance of $2.25 to $2.35 per share, which is consistent with our objective of growing EPS of 4% to 6% annually. Please note, our guidance ranges are based on several key assumptions, which are detailed in our earnings release. However, a couple of the 2017 assumptions are worth mentioning. We assume constructive regulatory outcomes in all proceedings. We're assuming sales growth of 0 to 0.5% in 2017, and O&M expenses are expected to stay flat with 2016 projections. This will mark a third year in a row of near flat O&M, reflecting our commitment to continuous improvement of our cost structure. 
Finally, we've updated our capital forecast and now expect to invest $18.4 billion over the next 5-year period of 2017 through 2021. This forecast drives annual rate base growth of 5.4%, using 2015 as a base. 
Capital plan reflects $3.5 billion of renewable investment, including the Rush Creek wind farm, our proposal to add 750 megawatts of wind in the Upper Midwest and incremental renewable generation to capitalize on our steel-for-fuel strategy. 
Again, it's important to point out that our capital investment in renewable generation is offset by fuel savings. So there's no impact on the customer build. Further, we don't plan to issue equity to fund this capital plan due to our strong balance sheet and credit metrics. 
In summary, we continue to execute on our strategic, financial and operational plan, with a strong quarter and are on track to deliver ongoing earnings within our guidance range for the 12th consecutive year. We reached a rate settlement in Minnesota and settlement principle in our Texas rate case. We're executing on our steel-for-fuel strategy with the approval of the Rush Creek wind project and the submittal of our 750 megawatt wind proposal in Minnesota and North Dakota. We've established 2017 earnings guidance consistent with our long-term growth objective of 4% to 6%. And finally, we've updated our 5-year capital forecast, which supports continual infrastructure investment in our service territory and delivers rate base growth of 5.4%. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, we'll now open the phone for questions.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. So Julien, remember, when we set a goal that we were going to cut the lag that we experienced between actual and authorized by 50 basis points by 2018. And that goal is still something we're very focused on. Some things have changed, of course.
componenttext: Yes, okay. So Julien, remember, when we set a goal that we were going to cut the lag that we experienced between actual and authorized by 50 basis points by 2018. And that goal is still something we're very focused on. Some things have changed, of course. Authorized ROEs have -- had fallen a bit, as you well know. So I think that for us to continue to improve ROEs, we'd really have to cut that lag by more than half and get closer to actually earning the authorized ROEs, which is, I think, more realistic for us than before because of some of the settlement agreements we've entered into. So count on us to show steady ROE improvement as we proceed down the 5-year path.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Got it. Can you comment real quickly on the renewable bucket of CapEx there? Just it seems if I do 19% times the new CapEx number, it might be a little bit higher than, I think, the couple of billion you previously discussed for renewables allocate
componenttext: Great. Got it. Can you comment real quickly on the renewable bucket of CapEx there? componenttext: Well, I'm going to -- I guess, I could walk you through it. And I -- we previously were at 15.2, right? Base cap. We believe we'll get with the approval of the 750 megawatts of wind. That adds another $700 million to the forecast. So that should bring it up to about 16.7, and then you add $1.5 billion for more steel-for-fuel opportunities that I think we have across all of our jurisdictions. And that should, if I had gotten that right, get you close to where we are.

componenttext: Yes. That's right, to roughly about $1.5 billion. And Julien, I think the -- we're confident that those opportunities will become reality, because -- I mean, the whole premise of steel-for-fuel is, you can do things on an economic basis, keeping on the fossil alternative. So in reality, the environmental benefits are the icing on the cake. So when you're not impacting customer bills and you're driving environmental leadership, it's really a unique position for us to be in.

componenttext: First, I wanted to clarify, as you mentioned, Ben, authorized ROEs, specifically uptick in Minnesota obviously have come down, part of the settlement. So when we run the math now and we look at your blended rated authorized ROE with the 9.2% number for Minnesota baked in there, it wasn't what you've earned over a 12-month period. What is the lag right now that you have in the overall utility system?

componenttext: The overall utility system or NSP-Min?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean -- I think this year, Ali, we're probably on around 9%, right? And so I think if you've blended all of our authorized ROEs, it'd probably be about 9.6%, roughly around there. So you got -- so that would be 60 basis points of lag, all right? T
componenttext: Well, I mean -- I think this year, Ali, we're probably on around 9%, right? And so I think if you've blended all of our authorized ROEs, it'd probably be about 9.6%, roughly around there. So you got -- so that would be 60 basis points of lag, all right? That's less than what we had before. Remember, when we first initiated that closed the gap, it was more like a 100 basis points of lag. So I think the challenge and the opportunity for us, Ali, is to -- for example, in Minnesota, clearly, that was a compromise 9.2%, it's not the ROE we would have preferred to have. However, when you look at the comprehensive settlement, we have a much better shot than we've ever had before of actually earning our allowed returns. And recall that in Minnesota, we have been lagging, frankly, more than 100 basis points. So we'll get at it differently. We've got a lower blended ROE base, but I think with multiyear plans -- comprehensive multiyear plans, we can probably do better than just cut the lag in half. And that's the plan.

componenttext: Yes. I mean -- I think, we do -- I won't say that we do have a regulatory amortization asset in 2017 that will create a bit of a headwind in Minnesota, all things equal. Our cost initiatives continue to gain traction, and we continue to stay focused on 2 critical aspects of shareholder value: growing rate base with our steel-for-fuel strategy; and keeping our costs as low as they possible can be, as we've done over the last 3 years, while not sacrificing reliability and not deferring necessary maintenance.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

So if I'm hearing it right, that's all now part of the base program, and then you've extended it by a year. First of all, just wanted to be clear, is that correct?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ali. I think that's right on the capital program. This is Bob. On the capital program, we had the base case and the upside capital that we used to disclose, and for clarity purposes, we put it all in one sort of capital forecast. As we've talked hist
componenttext: Yes, Ali. I think that's right on the capital program. This is Bob. On the capital program, we had the base case and the upside capital that we used to disclose, and for clarity purposes, we put it all in one sort of capital forecast. As we've talked historically about, I think we realized most of that upside case capital, and then we put additional wind and renewable development opportunities in our forecast.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ali -- I mean, I don't have it in front of me, but that 2.5, you're right. It had Rush Creek, it had like I think the 300 million of gas reserves. Of course, we're not going to do that now. It had some advanced grid opportunities, I believe, that is as
componenttext: So Ali -- I mean, I don't have it in front of me, but that 2.5, you're right. It had Rush Creek, it had like I think the 300 million of gas reserves. Of course, we're not going to do that now. It had some advanced grid opportunities, I believe, that is associated with the Northern Minnesota. And then, we had up some, I think, other renewable opportunities. So to Bob's point, we basically have achieved the upside CapEx just with renewables. And again, the clarity we'd seen with steel-for-fuel is really unique for us. And I think we'll continue to look for opportunities to transition the fleet, achieve remarkable carbon emission reductions at no additional price point to the consumer.

componenttext: I see. Last question also, and relative to now your new rate base growth forecast of 5.4%, if I equate that to your EPS growth aspiration of 4% to 6%. componenttext: No. Ali, I think you're spot on. I think you take that growth rate. We don't need to issue equity. We have an incredibly strong balance sheet. And so if we can see the ROE improvements, that will just drive you beyond the 5.4%.

componenttext: These guys nailed most of the questions I wanted to ask, but just to be clear, looking at your CapEx forecast now versus your prior CapEx forecast, the biggest delta is renewables, and that includes the plant that you've already had approved. The remaining CapEx is the assumption that you get the 750-megawatt self-build approved? Or is it that you get the 750-megawatt self-build approved, and then there's other placeholder CapEx for further renewables in the plan?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: To get you to the 18 4, you're right about Rush Creek in Colorado, which is approved. It also assumes that we have the opportunity to build half of the RFP. We think our self-build proposals are very compelling. And we could also get there through potenti
componenttext: To get you to the 18 4, you're right about Rush Creek in Colorado, which is approved. It also assumes that we have the opportunity to build half of the RFP. We think our self-build proposals are very compelling. And we could also get there through potentially build on transfer. But the assumption is that the capital associated with that RFP, half of that accrues to our shareholders and rate base. That leads a delta of about $1.5 billion, which are opportunities that we think are spread across all of our jurisdictions. We certainly could do more than 50% in Minnesota. I think there's more opportunities to do more in Colorado. And frankly, Greg, when you look at the economic price point that we believe that we are seeing with wind, I think we have opportunities potentially in Texas and New Mexico to just on the economic merits alone.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to focus on rate base growth, like some of the other questions, but in particular the kind of, I think, accelerated nature of that rate base growth within a potential 2016 to 2021 plan. So if you look at your Minnesota RFP, you have anticipated s
componenttext: I wanted to focus on rate base growth, like some of the other questions, but in particular the kind of, I think, accelerated nature of that rate base growth within a potential 2016 to 2021 plan. So if you look at your Minnesota RFP, you have anticipated start of construction for some of those projects in the middle of 2017, and then coming online kind of loosely before 2020. Is there potential to, if you're successful there, do that faster? And then when you combine that with the Colorado wind project coming online, and I think the fourth quarter of 2018 really front-load or find that some of the rate base growth is front-loaded towards the 2018 to 2019 period?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: May be something in 2019, but I think that's the practical realities of construction seasons, et cetera, probably -- I mean, I think we've got our best estimate.
componenttext: May be something in 2019, but I think that's the practical realities of construction seasons, et cetera, probably -- I mean, I think we've got our best estimate.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And secondly, on the dividends, when you look at your capital plan here, that's increased a lot since the prior one. And you combine that with a fact that you don't need, I think, any equity internal or external, how do you think about your 5% to 7%
componenttext: Okay. And secondly, on the dividends, when you look at your capital plan here, that's increased a lot since the prior one. And you combine that with a fact that you don't need, I think, any equity internal or external, how do you think about your 5% to 7% dividend growth guidance that you had previously laid out?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's pretty safe and pretty sustainable. I think, as you know, this was a delivered strategy that we had. We embarked upon an aggressive at the time, aggressive CapEx spend a decade ago and we deliberately during that time frame grew our to
componenttext: Well, I think it's pretty safe and pretty sustainable. I think, as you know, this was a delivered strategy that we had. We embarked upon an aggressive at the time, aggressive CapEx spend a decade ago and we deliberately during that time frame grew our to slower than our earnings growth, and that created a fortress balance sheet for us. So now, we have a modest payout ratio of 60%, 61% payout ratio. I think that's pretty low compared to our peers. It gives us a lot of what I would call dry powder. So count on the 5% to 7%. Although we would have, if interest rates start to rise and we see kind of the industry headwinds that would come with that, we certainly could step back and work with our board and determine if there's something else we need to do. I'm not saying we're going to do that, but it's just when you have a strong balance sheet deliberately created, it creates far more opportunities to reward shareholders. And that's something we're pretty proud of, quite frankly.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, just one more real quick, if I could. When you think about rolling forward your EPS growth CAGR potentially on the fourth quarter call, what kind of constraints might there -- be there on the regulatory front or on the Minnesota RFP front
componenttext: Okay. And then, just one more real quick, if I could. componenttext: I'm not quite sure [indiscernible].

componenttext: Just in terms of anything that would kind of hold you back in kind of releasing that number or caveats to the growth rate as a result of waiting for regulatory decisions?

componenttext: Chris, I think that the guidance we provide today is, we expect it to be consistent with fourth quarter and any roll forward in terms of capital and earnings and dividend. We don't expect that to change consistent with past practices. So we do expect regulatory outcomes that are reasonable. We lay out a host of assumptions that go into our '17 guidance, in our long-term earnings guidance in our earnings release today. We expect there's good assumptions for 2017.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, in terms of regulation around these renewable project or rate regulation around these, what's the current method that you expect to go forward with? I.e., is it just your traditional backward looking type of rate filings? Or is there a po
componenttext: I was wondering, in terms of regulation around these renewable project or rate regulation around these, what's the current method that you expect to go forward with? I.e., is it just your traditional backward looking type of rate filings? Or is there a potential there to convince regulators that with these multibillion type of investments, you could get rate riders or some kind of return on [indiscernible], something like that?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think what we're talking about here in Minnesota would be eligible for rider recovery. We've had those mechanisms in place for a while. So I think, recovery will be concurrent. The $1.5 billion that I talked about out, that will just depen
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think what we're talking about here in Minnesota would be eligible for rider recovery. We've had those mechanisms in place for a while. So I think, recovery will be concurrent. The $1.5 billion that I talked about out, that will just depend on what jurisdictions we do that in. Some will be eligible for riders. Some, we might propose some sort of enhanced type recovery mechanisms, as you suggest, Travis. So I think we're in really good shape with the renewable spend and getting recovery that doesn't have lag associated with it.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Similarly, Travis, in Colorado, the recovery of the Rush Creek wind farm is through riders as well.
componenttext: Similarly, Travis, in Colorado, the recovery of the Rush Creek wind farm is through riders as well.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one more general question. Obviously, the fuel-for-steel (sic) [ steel-for-fuel ], the next strategy for you guys. Is there any pushback on the regulatory front? I mean, is there anybody saying no, we shouldn't be doing this or we shouldn't be a
componenttext: Okay. And one more general question. Obviously, the fuel-for-steel (sic) [ steel-for-fuel ], the next strategy for you guys. Is there any pushback on the regulatory front? I mean, is there anybody saying no, we shouldn't be doing this or we shouldn't be allowing Xcel to be doing this?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know. I think people are pretty excited about it, actually. I mean, we -- when you can show -- let's talk about the Upper Midwest. When you can show regulators a plan that could achieve 60% carbon reduction and do that at no incremental price poin
componenttext: I don't know. I think people are pretty excited about it, actually. I mean, we -- when you can show -- let's talk about the Upper Midwest. When you can show regulators a plan that could achieve 60% carbon reduction and do that at no incremental price point from a -- to more traditional plan, it's pretty exciting. And no, we haven't seen pushback at all. We've seen a lot of excitement. In fact, I expect people to say, can you do more, which is usually the way these things work. And so -- no, I think it's created really good alignment with our stakeholders, quite frankly.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Angie Storozynski with Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Angie Storozynski with Macquarie.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just going back to the renewables being added to the rate base versus the lack of growth in power demand. I mean, I understand that renewables look cheaper than conventional power plants. But what happens with the assets that you have in the rate base?
componenttext: So just going back to the renewables being added to the rate base versus the lack of growth in power demand. I mean, I understand that renewables look cheaper than conventional power plants. But what happens with the assets that you have in the rate base? And when there's no growth in power demand and you keep adding generation assets?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Angie, I think that's a really good question, but let me try to answer it this way. I think what we're really doing with wind particularly is just really buying the fuel we're going to use tomorrow on sale today. So when you think about it -- I mean
componenttext: Well, Angie, I think that's a really good question, but let me try to answer it this way. I think what we're really doing with wind particularly is just really buying the fuel we're going to use tomorrow on sale today. So when you think about it -- I mean, it's not that it doesn't open up the dialogue for early retirement of coal plants, but essentially, what you're doing is you're displacing fossil fuels with wind. So you might still have the generation plant, the fossil generation plant, but you don't have to use it as much natural gas, even coal, when you're displacing that fuel with wind fuel. Does that make sense to you?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It completely does. It's just my question would be more -- I mean, you could buy this wind power from an outside provider that could probably use higher leverage on that project and granted the cost of capital, but it'll be probably slightly higher than y
componenttext: It completely does. It's just my question would be more -- I mean, you could buy this wind power from an outside provider that could probably use higher leverage on that project and granted the cost of capital, but it'll be probably slightly higher than yours, but again, the leverage ratios would be higher. So net-net, I mean, the cost of power would probably be similar. And I know that that would be an earnings neutral space for Xcel, but I'm just trying to figure out, from a regulatory risk perspective, if adding renewables through the rate base in the absence of rate growth is actually a low-risk growth strategy?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think -- I mean, whether it's contracted for or added to rate base, I don't think that influences very much your concern. I think maybe broader based, I don't think our rate base self-build proposals are going to -- they are going to be cost com
componenttext: I mean, I think -- I mean, whether it's contracted for or added to rate base, I don't think that influences very much your concern. I think maybe broader based, I don't think our rate base self-build proposals are going to -- they are going to be cost competitive, even with the leverage that others use, of course, banking on our strong balance sheet to support that, there is an element to that. And I think our regulators were well aware of that and appreciate the benefits of utility ownership. So I really think that when you pencil out the numbers, you'll see how compelling, particularly when you do on a fully holistic basis, how compelling our proposals are.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: I mean, if you think -- it's also important to recognize that there is some of these wind resources are being added to reflect the fact that there are coal plants being retired in the future. So we're just taking opportunity to capture the full PTC. So maybe the -- so when it comes down to service a little before to some of the coal requirements, like Sherco, but I think we're trying to accomplish that.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Angie, I think that's -- Paul made a great point. Because when we're talking about early retirement of coal plants, this is our resource plan. And we're the ones that are leading the decarbonization of our fleet. And I think we will show that we
componenttext: Yes, and Angie, I think that's -- Paul made a great point. Because when we're talking about early retirement of coal plants, this is our resource plan. And we're the ones that are leading the decarbonization of our fleet. And I think we will show that we can build wind competitively, and I think we've earned the right to own wind in our backyard. And it's all part of an overall plan. And again, I think it does require alignment with your regulators, but I think we have it.

componenttext: Well, I mean, I think, Andy, as you know, I think we've got -- if we can execute on both the rate base growth and the ROE improvement, we're going to be at the top of that range, maybe potentially beyond it. componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think the fundamental, when we look at it, it's just swapping fuel for, in this case, wind fuel, okay? But it -- the fuel swap alone will work, but then it sets up the dialogue about ultimately what your portfolio is going to look like. So -- go ahead.

componenttext: Well, that anticipated my question, actually. So I don't know what do you keep going there. Or I mean, any other sort of incremental things that could actually be more than just an offset, it could actually be seen, if you took all the things into account, a net benefit for customers. headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you're right. Now cost of carbon, of course, it's an exercise outside of the pure economics, right? So I mean, you're implying a societal benefit and that sort of thing, which we're not opposed to. But what we're focused on is just the straigh
componenttext: No, I think you're right. Now cost of carbon, of course, it's an exercise outside of the pure economics, right? So I mean, you're implying a societal benefit and that sort of thing, which we're not opposed to. But what we're focused on is just the straight-up numbers of what we can do, capturing 100% PTC with wind, with fuel. And then, that can allow you to have further dialogues around, as I mentioned, the earlier shutdown of coal plants, the O&M and all the other things that go with that. You start to design your portfolio to be more low following, because if you look at where we think we're going to be in 2030 and our carbon reductions, I think we have system in the upper Midwest, we'll have 15% of our energy mix from coal. It's -- you need to make sure your generation portfolio has been designed in a way that you can accommodate these additional renewable resources without sacrificing reliability. That's all part of our planning process. I mean -- so the short answer to your question was yes.

componenttext: I do think -- here's what we believe. We believe solar and wind will continue to fall on price, the continuous improvement we'd seen. However, the PTCs, as you know, start to fall off at 20% each year after this year. And so I think the prices we are hopefully going to lock in for our customers today at 100% PTC, even with the technological improvements, you will not see prices this strong again until probably the -- or this low again, rather, until probably the mid-20s.

componenttext: Because it's still -- Shelby, it's very modest. And as you know, we've always had the philosophy, there's a benefit of strength in numbers. You get a -- if you're an operating utility and as part of a larger group, you do get a consolidation benefit, provided there is an excessive leverage at the Holdco, and we're not even close to that. All of our utilities benefit from being part of a bigger group, and that's always been our approach and that will continue to be our approach. And we'd never do anything that would be harmful to the credit ratings of our utilities. And I think our track record speaks for itself on that.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy's 2016 Third Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Bob Frenzel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy's 2016 Third Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Bob Frenzel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition, we have other members of the management team in the room to answer your questions. 
This morning, we will review our third quarter results, initiate 2017 guidance, update you on recent business and regulatory development and update our 5-year capital forecast, financing plan and rate base growth. 
As a reminder, some of the comments during today's conference call may contain forward-looking information. Significant factors that could cause results to differ from those anticipated are described in our earnings release and our filings with the SEC. 
I'll now turn the call over to Ben.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul, and good morning, everyone. Today, we reported third quarter GAAP and ongoing earnings of $0.90 per share compared with $0.84 per share last year. Year-to-date, we're $0.07 per share ahead of last year, and as a result, we're narrowing ov
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul, and good morning, everyone. Today, we reported third quarter GAAP and ongoing earnings of $0.90 per share compared with $0.84 per share last year. Year-to-date, we're $0.07 per share ahead of last year, and as a result, we're narrowing over 2016 guidance range to $2.17 to $2.22 per share from the previous range of $2.12 to $2.27 per share. We still anticipate earnings in the middle of the range. We're also initiating 2017 earnings guidance of $2.25 to $2.35 per share, which is consistent with our long-term EPS growth objective of 4% to 6%. 
We had a productive quarter, and we continue to make progress on investment plans and regulatory issues. I'll briefly touch on some of the highlights. 
Today, we are updating our 5-year capital forecast and you will notice a significant increase in renewable investments. Therefore, I'm going to spend a few minutes discussing our steel-for-fuel strategy. Our service territory is unique in its concentration of renewable rich resources. For example, the capacity factors for wind generation are approximately 50% in Minnesota and Texas and about 45% in Colorado. When you combine high capacity factors, a strong transmission network and the extension of the production tax credit, it all translates into low renewable energy cost for our customers. Today, we can add wind energy, which meets or beats the cost of fossil generation resources. Because of the strong wind resources in our backyard, we have the unique opportunity to invest in renewable generation in which the capital costs are offset by fuel savings. Therefore, we are lowering the emission profile of our generation fleet with significant fuel savings, which allows us to grow our renewable portfolio with no impact to customer bills. A prime example of our steel-for-fuel strategy is the Rush Creek wind project in Colorado. In September, the Colorado Commission approved our request to develop the 600-megawatt wind farm with a capital investment of approximately $1 billion. We will start initial work on the project this year, and it's expected to go into service in 2018. Another example is in Minnesota, where the commission recently approved our resource plan, which includes the early retirements of 2 coal units at our Sherco facility and the addition of a significant amount of renewable energy. In accordance with the resource plan, we have issued an RFP to add up to 1,500 megawatts of wind generation. This week, we filed a self-build proposal to develop 750 megawatts of wind generation, which will meet half of that resource need. We believe that our projects reflect competitive pricing and are confident that the commission will approve our proposal in the first half of 2017. We expect both of these wind projects will generate hundreds of millions of dollars in fuel savings for our customers, which will more than offset the capital cost, highlighting the benefit of our steel-for-fuel strategy. 
Turning to the operations side of the business. More than a decade ago, we partnered with a group of smaller utilities to form CapX2020 and transform the transmission grid in the upper Midwest. That transformation was made a reality with the recent completion and energizing of the 156-mile Hampton-Rochester-La Crosse transmission line. CapX2020 has now invested $1.9 billion in completing 4 high-voltage transmission lines, totaling nearly 725 miles. A fifth project in South Dakota is scheduled for completion in 2017. These transmission projects are addressing the liability needs and increasing access to renewable energy across the Upper Midwest. 
I'll now turn the call over to Bob to provide more detail on our financial results and outlook in addition to our regulatory update.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben, and good morning. Today, we reported GAAP and ongoing earnings of $0.90 per share for the quarter versus the $0.84 per share earned last year. The most significant earnings drivers in the quarter include: higher electric and natural gas mar
componenttext:
Thanks, Ben, and good morning. 
Today, we reported GAAP and ongoing earnings of $0.90 per share for the quarter versus the $0.84 per share earned last year. The most significant earnings drivers in the quarter include: higher electric and natural gas margins, which increased earnings by $0.15 per share, largely due to rate increases and capital rider recovery for infrastructure investments, along with sales growth and favorable weather. We also realized the lower effective income tax rate due to higher PTCs from wind projects, which increased earnings by $0.02 per share. Partially offsetting these positive drivers were increased depreciation expense largely due to capital additions and reductions in excess depreciation and reserves, which reduced earnings by $0.06 per share and higher interest and O&M expenses, which, combined, reduced earnings by $0.05 per share. 
Our third quarter electric sales came in stronger than expected and increased 1.6% on a weather-adjusted basis. We saw positive sales growth in the residential and C&I classes. We continue to experience strong customer growth of approximately 1% for both our electric and our natural gas businesses. While we're happy to see a quarter of strong sales, it's a little early to call it a trend, and our year-to-date weather-adjusted electric sales remain relatively flat. Therefore, we remain cautious on the sales outlook and anticipate flat year-over-year sales. 
We're very focused on managing our cost structure for the benefit of our customers. Our year-to-date O&M expenses are approximately 1% above last year. We experienced higher storm cost and maintenance expense in the third quarter and expect full year O&M to be slightly above 2015 actuals. We continue to mitigate O&M increases through our efforts to improve productivity through capital investment and ease of technology, and we expect to carry this effort into the future. 
During the quarter, we made significant progress in a number of proceedings across our territories. You'll find more details in our earnings release, but let me provide some highlights. 
Consistent with our strategy to implement longer-term rate plan in our jurisdictions, we reached a preliminary settlement with the majority of parties in our Minnesota electric rate case, which will provide revenue certainty through 2019. The terms for the full year plan include: an ROE of 9.2% and an equity ratio of 52.5%, an annual sales true-up that continued use of all existing riders, a 4-year rate case stay-out provision, a property tax true-up and a capital true-up mechanism. We expect an ALJ report in March of 2017 and a final commission decision in June of 2017. As a reminder, interim rates subject to refund are in place while the commission considers the case. 
We're pleased to announce that we've reached a settlement and agreement in principle in our Texas rate case, and hearings have been vacated. We're working on documenting the settlement and plan to file it in the fourth quarter. Although we can't provide any details until the documentation is finalized, we believe that the settlement is positive and reflects a growing constructive regulatory environment in Texas and New Mexico. 
Finally, we also have a pending rate case in Wisconsin where we requested a revised rate increase of approximately $35 million between electric and natural gas. Just yesterday, the Wisconsin commission verbally approved a combined increase of approximately $27 million, which reflects complete recovery of our requested natural gas rate increase and an adjusted electric rate increase. Final rates will be implemented in January. 
Turning to earnings guidance. Based on our year-to-date results, we are narrowing our 2016 ongoing earnings guidance range to $2.17 to $2.22 per share. Previously, the range was $2.12 to $2.22 per share. We are also initiating our 2017 ongoing earnings guidance of $2.25 to $2.35 per share, which is consistent with our objective of growing EPS of 4% to 6% annually. Please note, our guidance ranges are based on several key assumptions, which are detailed in our earnings release. However, a couple of the 2017 assumptions are worth mentioning. We assume constructive regulatory outcomes in all proceedings. We're assuming sales growth of 0 to 0.5% in 2017, and O&M expenses are expected to stay flat with 2016 projections. This will mark a third year in a row of near flat O&M, reflecting our commitment to continuous improvement of our cost structure. 
Finally, we've updated our capital forecast and now expect to invest $18.4 billion over the next 5-year period of 2017 through 2021. This forecast drives annual rate base growth of 5.4%, using 2015 as a base. 
Capital plan reflects $3.5 billion of renewable investment, including the Rush Creek wind farm, our proposal to add 750 megawatts of wind in the Upper Midwest and incremental renewable generation to capitalize on our steel-for-fuel strategy. 
Again, it's important to point out that our capital investment in renewable generation is offset by fuel savings. So there's no impact on the customer bills. Further, we don't plan to issue equity to fund this capital plan due to our strong balance sheet and credit metrics. 
In summary, we continue to execute on our strategic, financial and operational plan, with a strong quarter and are on track to deliver ongoing earnings within our guidance range for the 12th consecutive year. We reached a rate settlement in Minnesota and settlement principle in our Texas rate case. We're executing on our steel-for-fuel strategy with the approval of the Rush Creek wind project and the submittal of our 750 megawatt wind proposal in Minnesota and North Dakota. We've established 2017 earnings guidance consistent with our long-term growth objective of 4% to 6%. And finally, we've updated our 5-year capital forecast, which supports continual infrastructure investment in our service territory and delivers rate base growth of 5.4%. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, we'll now open the phone for questions.

componenttext: Well, I mean -- I think this year, Ali, we're probably on around 9%, right? We've got a lower blended ROE base, but I think with multiyear plans -- comprehensive multiyear plans, we can probably do better than just cut the lag in half. And that's the plan.

componenttext: To get you to the 18 4, you're right about the Rush Creek in Colorado, which is approved. It also assumes that we have the opportunity to build half of the RFP. That leads a delta of about $1.5 billion, which are opportunities that we think are spread across all of our jurisdictions. We certainly could do more than 50% in Minnesota. I think there's more opportunities to do more in Colorado. And frankly, Greg, when you look at the economic price point that we believe that we are seeing with wind, I think we have opportunities potentially in Texas and New Mexico to adjust on the economic merits alone.

componenttext: Okay. And secondly, on the dividends, when you look at your capital plan here, that's increased a lot since the prior one. And you combine that with a fact that you don't need, I think, any equity internal or external, how do you think about your 5% to 7% dividend growth guidance that you had previously laid out?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's pretty safe and pretty sustainable. I think, as you know, this was a delivered strategy that we had. We embarked upon an aggressive at the time, aggressive CapEx spend a decade ago and we deliberately during that time frame grew our to
componenttext: Well, I think it's pretty safe and pretty sustainable. I think, as you know, this was a delivered strategy that we had. We embarked upon an aggressive at the time, aggressive CapEx spend a decade ago and we deliberately during that time frame grew our to slower than our earnings growth, and that created a fortress balance sheet for us. So now, we have a modest payout ratio of 60%, 61% payout ratio. I think that's pretty low compared to our peers. It gives us a lot of what I would call dry powder. So count on the 5% to 7%. But what we would have, if interest rates start to rise and we see kind of the industry headwinds that would come with that, we certainly could step back and work with our board and determine if there's something else we need to do. I'm not saying we're going to do that, but it's just when you have a strong balance sheet deliberately created, it creates far more opportunities to reward shareholders. And that's something we're pretty proud of, quite frankly.

componenttext: I was wondering, in terms of regulation around these renewable projects or rate regulation around these, what's the current method that you expect to go forward with? I.e., is it just your traditional backward-looking type of rate filings? Or is there a potential there to convince regulators that with these multibillion type of investments, you could get rate riders or some kind of return on quip [ph], something like that?

componenttext: Well, I mean, I think what we're talking about here in Minnesota would be eligible for rider recovery. We've had those mechanisms in place for a while. I mean, is there anybody saying no, we shouldn't be doing this or we shouldn't be allowing Xcel to be doing this?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know. I think people are pretty excited about it, actually. I mean, we -- when you can show -- let's talk about the Upper Midwest. When you can show regulators a plan that could achieve 60% carbon reduction and do that at no incremental price poin
componenttext: I don't know. I think people are pretty excited about it, actually. I mean, we -- when you can show -- let's talk about the Upper Midwest. When you can show regulators a plan that could achieve 60% carbon reduction and do that at no incremental price point from a -- to more traditional plan, it's pretty exciting. And no, we haven't seen pushback at all. We've seen a lot of excitement. In fact, I expect people to say, can you do more, which is usually the way these things work. And so -- no, I think it's created really good alignment with our stakeholders, quite frankly.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one of the drivers on the quarter was a lower tax rate because of higher PTCs. Is that a function of -- I think the wind is a little weaker than normal last year and it was more normal this year?
componenttext: So one of the drivers on the quarter was a lower tax rate because of higher PTCs. Is that a function of -- I think the wind is a little weaker than normal last year and it was more normal this year?

componenttext: Paul, this is Bob. We put 2 wind farms into service in 2016. So year-over-year, effective tax rate's just going to be lower due to the PTCs for those 2 farms.

componenttext: There's not -- I'm not sure how the rate making works, but is there exposure to a low wind regime so that you have a particularly weak quarter? Or is that sought through the fuel cost?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Angie Storozynski with Macquarie.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just going back to the renewables being added to the rate base versus the lack of growth in power demand. I mean, I understand that renewables look cheaper than conventional power plants. But what happens with the assets that you have in the rate base?
componenttext: So just going back to the renewables being added to the rate base versus the lack of growth in power demand. I mean, I understand that renewables look cheaper than conventional power plants. But what happens with the assets that you have in the rate base? And when there's no growth in power demand and you keep adding generation assets?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Angie, I think that's a really good question, but let me try to answer it this way. I think what we're really doing with wind particularly is just really buying the fuel we're going to use tomorrow on sale today. So when you think about it -- I mean
componenttext: Well, Angie, I think that's a really good question, but let me try to answer it this way. I think what we're really doing with wind particularly is just really buying the fuel we're going to use tomorrow on sale today. So when you think about it -- I mean, it's not that it doesn't open up the dialogue for early retirement of coal plants, but essentially, what you're doing is you're displacing fossil fuels with wind. So you might still have the generation plant, the fossil generation plant, but you don't have to use it as much natural gas, even coal, when you're displacing that fuel with wind fuel. Does that make sense to you?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It completely does. It's just my question would be more -- I mean, you could buy this wind power from an outside provider that could probably use higher leverage on that project and granted the cost of capital will be probably slightly higher than yours,
componenttext: It completely does. It's just my question would be more -- I mean, you could buy this wind power from an outside provider that could probably use higher leverage on that project and granted the cost of capital will be probably slightly higher than yours, but again, the leverage ratios would be higher. So net-net, I mean, the cost of power would probably be similar. And I know that that would be an earnings neutral space [ph] for Xcel, but I'm just trying to figure out, from a regulatory risk perspective, if adding renewables through the rate base in the absence of vote [ph] growth is actually a low-risk growth strategy?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think -- I mean, whether it's contracted for or added to rate base, I don't think that influence is very much your concern. I think maybe broader based. I don't think our rate-based self-build proposals are going to -- they are going to be cost
componenttext: I mean, I think -- I mean, whether it's contracted for or added to rate base, I don't think that influence is very much your concern. I think maybe broader based. I don't think our rate-based self-build proposals are going to -- they are going to be cost competitive, even with the leverage that others use, of course, banking on our strong balance sheet to support that, there is an element to that. And I think our regulators were well aware of that and appreciate the benefits of utility ownership. So I really think that when you pencil out the numbers, you'll see how compelling, particularly when you do on a fully holistic basis, how compelling our proposals are.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Angie, I think it's also important to recognize that there is some of these wind resources are being added to reflect the fact that there are coal plants being retired in the future. So we're just taking opportunity to capture the full PTC. So maybe the -
componenttext: Angie, I think it's also important to recognize that there is some of these wind resources are being added to reflect the fact that there are coal plants being retired in the future. So we're just taking opportunity to capture the full PTC. So maybe the -- so wind comes down service a little before some of the coal requirements, like Sherco, but I think we're trying to accomplish that.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Angie, I think that's -- Paul made a great point. Because when we're talking about early retirement of coal plants, this is our resource plan. And we're the ones that are leading the decarbonization of our fleet. And I think we will show that we
componenttext: Yes, and Angie, I think that's -- Paul made a great point. Because when we're talking about early retirement of coal plants, this is our resource plan. And we're the ones that are leading the decarbonization of our fleet. And I think we will show that we can build wind competitively, and I think we've earned the right to own wind in our backyard. And it's all part of an overall plan. And again, I think it does require alignment with your regulators, but I think we have it.

Or what's -- I mean, just based on what the numbers we're running, I'm just wondering why $5 billion versus like $3.5 billion?
